Burke Andersen, the Danish filmmaker best known for his surrealist and surrealist-inflected films, has died at age eighty-three.Born in Copenhagen in 1931, Andersen moved to Copenhagen in 1943 to study at the University of Copenhagen. There, he met and befriended Susan and worked with A.A. Paxton, who would become his wife and provide the inspiration for the filmography of Andersen. By the early 1950s, he had developed a preoccupation with the human body. Andersen would go on to pursue his own body, eschewing the traditional narrative in favor of an exploration of the body as an agent of change and art.Among the many works that bear his name are The Body in Film (1949), The Body in Film (1950), The Body in Film II (1954), and The Body in Film III (1960).
